statements.name: PROC RISK
statements.description: Begins a RISK procedure code block.

statements.name: ARRAY
statements.description: Creates one or more arrays that group risk factor variables together to represent yield curves, other types of vector data, and risk factor surfaces.
statements.help:
ARRAY  name role ELEMENTS = ( element-list )  <optional_argument(s)>  ARRAY  name role DIMENSIONS = ( dim1name (timegrid1name) <dim2name(timegrid2name)> ) 
	 <optional_argument(s)>  ARRAY   name  role TIMEGRID = "time-grid-name"  <optional_argument(s)>

arguments.name: name
arguments.description: specifies the name of the array.

arguments.name: role
arguments.description: specifies one of the following purposes of the array:

arguments.name: ELEMENTS=
arguments.description: specifies that the array elements are the risk factor variables that are specified in the element-list. If you specify the ELEMENTS= argument in an array definition, then do not specify the DIMENSIONS= or TIMEGRID= argument.

arguments.name: DIMENSIONS=
arguments.description: TIMEGRID = argument is valid only for FX, IR, and VAR roles. The DIMENSIONS = argument enables you to specify time grids for roles FXSURFACE, IRSURFACE, and SURFACE. For example, the following code defines a risk factor array, called MV, using time grids. The risk factor array MV contains risk factor surfaces with dimensions maturity and volatility.

arguments.name: TIMEGRID=
arguments.description: for one-dimensional arrays, specifies that the array elements are the maturities that are defined in a specified time grid. The number of array elements must equal the number of elements in the time grid. If you specify the TIMEGRID = argument, then you do not need to specify the ELEMENTS = or DIMENSIONS = argument in an array definition.

arguments.name: CATEGORY=
arguments.description: assigns the array to one or more risk factor categories.

arguments.name: CURRENCY=
arguments.description: specifies the currency for an interest rate curve array.

arguments.name: DESC
arguments.description: specifies a descriptive label for the array. Longer labels are truncated to 80 characters.

arguments.name: EXTRAPOLATE=
arguments.description: specifies how outlying values should be treated during interpolation. Valid only for risk factor surfaces. Outlying values are less than the lower endpoint or greater than the upper endpoint. When EXTRAPOLATE=CONSTANT, x[1] or x[n] is returned. When EXTRAPOLATE=MISSING, missing is returned. MISSING is the default.

arguments.name: FROMCUR
arguments.description: specifies the initial currency of a foreign exchange rate curve.

arguments.name: GROUP=
arguments.description: assigns a group name to the array. This name is truncated to 32 characters. Use this argument to customize how curves are displayed in the SAS Risk Dimensions user interface. If an array definition does not include a GROUP= specification, then the array is assigned to a group with the same name as its role.

arguments.name: INTERPOLATE=
arguments.description: specifies an interpolation type. Valid only for one-dimensional risk factor surfaces.
arguments.help: INTERPOLATE=LINEAR | LOGLINEAR | CUBIC | STEP | FWDRATE | SPLINE<(NOTAKNOTNATURAL)>

arguments.name: LONGLABEL=
arguments.description: specifies a long description for the array. Maximum length is 512 characters.

arguments.name: REFMAP=
arguments.description: specifies the key values to use to resolve a risk factor curve for the specified reference variables. The reference key value list is a list of specifications that have the form reference-variable = “key-value”.

arguments.name: TOCUR
arguments.description: specifies the target currency of a foreign exchange rate curve.

statements.name: CASHFLOW
statements.description: Creates a cash flow analysis specification.

arguments.name: name
arguments.description: specifies the name of the cash flow analysis specification.

arguments.name: ANALYSIS=
arguments.description: specifies the type of cash flow analysis. If you specify TRADITIONAL, then the cash flow analysis is based on the base case market state. This analysis meets the usual needs of a static gap analysis of cash flow buckets, durations, and interest income.

arguments.name: BUCKETTYPE
arguments.description: specifies one of the following cash flow bucketing types:

arguments.name: DESC
arguments.description: specifies a descriptive label for the cash flow. Longer labels are truncated to 80 characters.

arguments.name: DURATION=
arguments.description: specifies one of the following duration types:

arguments.name: EVALDATE=
arguments.description: updates the value of the _date_ variable after market state generation. This affects subsequent method calls and result calculations.

arguments.name: LONGLABEL=
arguments.description: specifies a long description for the cash flow. Maximum length is 512 characters.

statements.name: COUNTERPARTY
statements.description: Creates a counterparty type that is associated with counterparty variables, methods, and models.

arguments.name: name
arguments.description: specifies the name of the counterparty type.

arguments.name: BASETYPE
arguments.description: specifies the parent counterparty from which a child counterparty type can inherit the scoring method, model, and variables.

arguments.name: DESC
arguments.description: specifies a descriptive label for the counterparty type. Longer labels are truncated to 80 characters.

arguments.name: LONGLABEL=
arguments.description: specifies a long description for the counterparty type. Maximum length is 512 characters.

arguments.name: MCREPS=
arguments.description: specifies the number of times that counterparty types are called when you perform a Monte Carlo pricing. Output variables are averaged across the specified number. The default value of number is 2. Use this argument when MCTYPE=AVERAGE.

arguments.name: MCTYPE=
arguments.description: specifies a Monte Carlo counterparty type. This counterparty type is supported by SAS High-Performance Risk. The associated pricing method is called in a loop MCREPS times across horizons. Specify MCREPS explicitly or through the value of MCSIMULATIONS in the PROC HPRISK statement.

arguments.name: METHOD=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the scoring method.

arguments.name: MODEL
arguments.description: specifies a scoring model to use that has been previously stored in the SAS Metadata Repository by SAS Enterprise Miner. Specify the model with its three-level name that has the form libref.SAS-dataset. model-name.

arguments.name: VARIABLES=
arguments.description: specifies the variables that are associated with the counterparty type.

statements.name: CPTYDATA
statements.description: Creates a counterparty data source, which the READ statement uses to create a risk object used in a portfolio.

arguments.name: data-source-name
arguments.description: specifies the name of the counterparty data source.

arguments.name: FILE=
arguments.description: specifies the input data set (or data view) that contains the counterparty data.

arguments.name: DESC
arguments.description: specifies a descriptive label for the counterparty data source. Longer labels are truncated to 80 characters.

arguments.name: LONGLABEL=
arguments.description: specifies a long description for the counterparty data source. Maximum length is 512 characters.

arguments.name: TYPE=
arguments.description: specifies that all counterparties in the input file have the same counterparty type, namely that specified by counterparty-type-name. If the counterparty type varies across counterparties in the file, then do not specify this argument. Maximum length is 32 characters.

arguments.name: VARIABLES=
arguments.description: maps variable names in the input data set to counterparty variable names. Usually, this argument is used only if the names of the counterparty fields differ between the data set and the counterparty definition.

statements.name: CROSSCLASS
statements.description: Creates a cross-classification that specifies the instrument variables and system instrument information variables by which analysis results are reported. These results are reported in addition to the results for the aggregate portfolio. NOTE: Including this statement in your PROC RISK block has no effect on the SAS High-Performance Risk project run.

arguments.name: name
arguments.description: specifies the name of the cross-classification.

arguments.name: DESC
arguments.description: specifies a descriptive label for the cross-classification. Longer labels are truncated to 80 characters.

arguments.name: LONGLABEL=
arguments.description: specifies a long description for the cross-classification. Maximum length is 512 characters.

statements.name: DECLARE
statements.description: Creates variable declarations that specify the names and attributes of variables.

arguments.name: variable-declaration
arguments.description:
Variable declaration include:
• CPTYVARS
• INSTVARS | LOANVARS
• MITIGATIONVARS
• OUTVARS
• PROJVARS
• REFERENCES
• RISKFACTORS
• STATEVARS

arguments.name: name
arguments.description: specifies the name of the variable.

arguments.name: type
arguments.description: specifies the data type of the variable. See the table below for a listing of the types that you can use in each variable declaration.

arguments.name: role
arguments.description: specifies the purpose of the variable. See the table below for a listing of the roles that you can use in each variable declaration.

arguments.name: ALPOS
arguments.description: specifies whether to apply each position’s asset-liability position flag to an output variable. The flag is a multiplier of 1 or of –1. The default value is NOALPOS.

arguments.name: NOALPOS
arguments.description: specifies whether to apply each position’s asset-liability position flag to an output variable. The flag is a multiplier of 1 or of –1. The default value is NOALPOS.

arguments.name: BASEVAR=
arguments.description: specifies the risk factor for which a variable provides a volatility estimate. This argument is required in variable definitions with the VOLATILITY role.

arguments.name: COMPTYPE=
arguments.description: specifies whether an output variable should be treated as profit/loss, value, or exposure.

arguments.name: COORDINATES=
arguments.description: specifies the coordinates of the risk factor. The risk factor can have one or two dimensions. The customary dimension “maturity” is available but not necessary when the role is VAR or VOLATILITY. When the role is FX, FX_SPOT, or IR, then you must specify “maturity” as one of the dimensions. The following code provides an illustration:

arguments.name: CURRENCY=
arguments.description: specifies the currency for an interest rate variable. This argument is required in variable definitions with the IR role.

arguments.name: DESC
arguments.description: specifies a descriptive label for the variable. Longer labels are truncated to 80 characters.

arguments.name: DROP
arguments.description: drops the variable from the output data sets.

arguments.name: FORMAT=
arguments.description: applies a specified SAS format to the variable values.

arguments.name: FROMCUR=
arguments.description: specifies the initial currency of a foreign exchange rate variable. This argument is required for variables with the roles FX and FX_SPOT.

arguments.name: GROUP=
arguments.description: assigns a group name to the variable. This name is truncated to 32 characters. This argument is used to customize how variables are displayed in the SAS Risk Dimensions user interface. If a variable definition does not include a GROUP= specification, then the variable is assigned to a group with the same name as its role.

arguments.name: FX
arguments.description: specifies whether the returned value from pricing methods should be multiplied by the appropriate foreign exchange rate. If you do not specify this argument, then the returned pricing method value is multiplied by the foreign exchange rate.

arguments.name: NOFX
arguments.description: specifies whether the returned value from pricing methods should be multiplied by the appropriate foreign exchange rate. If you do not specify this argument, then the returned pricing method value is multiplied by the foreign exchange rate.

arguments.name: HOLDING
arguments.description: specifies whether the returned value from pricing methods should be multiplied by the holding amount. If you do not specify this argument, then the returned pricing method value is multiplied by the holding amount.

arguments.name: NOHOLDING
arguments.description: specifies whether the returned value from pricing methods should be multiplied by the holding amount. If you do not specify this argument, then the returned pricing method value is multiplied by the holding amount.

arguments.name: LAGGRID=
arguments.description: specifies the time grid that contains the lag points of the variable. For the base case market state, lag values are read from the time series market data source that you specify in the PROJECT statement. For subsequent market states, lag values are derived (potentially interpolated) from the lag values read for the base case, the base case value, and the values calculated for prior horizons.

arguments.name: LONGLABEL=
arguments.description: specifies a long description for the variable. Maximum length is 512 characters.

arguments.name: MATURITY=
arguments.description: assigns a maturity (for example, 2 year) to the variable. If you do not specify a maturity unit, then the maturity unit is set to year.

arguments.name: MLEVEL=
arguments.description:
specifies the measurement level of the variable. This argument affects how simulated shocks are generated and applied to the risk factor in historical data or covariance simulation analysis. (Monte Carlo simulations are not affected.) This argument also affects how volatility changes are applied during scenario simulation.
• An INTERVAL measurement level denotes a variable, such as money flows or time before an event, that has interval scale values. In a simulation analysis, additive changes are applied to risk factor values. LEVEL and ADDITIVE are aliases for INTERVAL. 
• RATIO measurement level denotes a variable, such as prices or interest rates, that has nonnegative ratio scale values. In a simulation analysis, additive changes are applied to risk factor values. RATE and RELATIVE are aliases for RATIO. 
• GBM measurement level also denotes a variable, such as prices or interest rates, that have nonnegative ratio scale values. It simulates using geometric Brownian motion and applies only to covariance simulation. For any other simulation, GBM reverts to a RATIO measurement level.

arguments.name: POSTVAR
arguments.description: specifies whether the output variable is computed in PostVaR methods.

arguments.name: REFMAP=
arguments.description: specifies the key values to use to resolve a risk factor for the specified reference variables. The reference key value list is a list of specifications that have the form reference-variable= “key-value.”

arguments.name: ROLLUP=
arguments.description: specifies one of the following methods for output variable aggregation:

arguments.name: SHORTPOS
arguments.description: specifies whether the returned value from pricing methods should be multiplied by the short position flag, if appropriate. If you do not specify this argument, then the returned pricing method value is multiplied by the short position flag.

arguments.name: NOSHORTPOS
arguments.description: specifies whether the returned value from pricing methods should be multiplied by the short position flag, if appropriate. If you do not specify this argument, then the returned pricing method value is multiplied by the short position flag.

arguments.name: TOCUR=
arguments.description: specifies the target currency of a foreign exchange rate variable. The TOCUR= argument is required for variables with the roles FX and FX_SPOT.

statements.name: DELETE
statements.description: Deletes objects from the current environment.

arguments.name: ANALYSIS=
arguments.description: deletes one or more analysis specifications.

arguments.name: ARRAY=
arguments.description: deletes one or more arrays created by the ARRAY statement. The VARIABLE argument can also be used to delete arrays.

arguments.name: COUNTERPARTY=
arguments.description: deletes one or more counterparty types.

arguments.name: CPTYDATA=
arguments.description: deletes one or more counterparty data sources.

arguments.name: CROSSCLASS=
arguments.description: deletes one or more cross-classifications.

arguments.name: DISTORTION=
arguments.description: deletes one or more distortion measures.

arguments.name: ENVIRONMENT=
arguments.description: deletes one or more environments.

arguments.name: FILTER=
arguments.description: deletes one or more portfolio filters.

arguments.name: INSTDATA=
arguments.description: deletes one or more instrument data sources.

arguments.name: INSTRUMENT=
arguments.description: deletes one or more instrument types. This argument performs the same function as the ACCOUNT, ASSET, and POLICY arguments.

arguments.name: MARKETDATA=
arguments.description: deletes one or more market data sources.

arguments.name: METHOD=
arguments.description: deletes one or more methods.

arguments.name: MITDATA=
arguments.description: deletes one or more mitigation data sources.

arguments.name: MITIGATION=
arguments.description: deletes one or more mitigation types.

arguments.name: PARAMETER=
arguments.description: deletes one or more parameter matrices.

arguments.name: PROJECT=
arguments.description: deletes one or more analysis projects.

arguments.name: RFTSET=
arguments.description: deletes one or more risk factor transformation sets.

arguments.name: SCENARIO_CF=
arguments.description: deletes one or more scenario cash flow data objects.

arguments.name: SOURCES=
arguments.description: deletes one or more portfolio input lists.

arguments.name: TIMEGRID=
arguments.description: deletes one or more time grids.

arguments.name: TRANSMAT=
arguments.description: deletes one or more transition matrices.

arguments.name: VARIABLE=
arguments.description: deletes one or more instrument, counterparty, mitigation, risk factor, output, state, project, or reference variables. To delete all variables created with the DECLARE statement, specify the following:

statements.name: DELTANORMAL
statements.description: Creates a Delta-Normal analysis specification.

arguments.name: name
arguments.description: specifies the name of the Delta-Normal analysis.

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: specifies either a covariance, correlation, or time series market data source. This data source must be consistent with the interval that is specified by the INTERVAL argument. The covariance or correlation matrix describes the dependence between the risk factors. If a time series market data source is provided, SAS Risk Dimensions uses it to compute a covariance matrix.

arguments.name: ALIGN=
arguments.description: specifies one of the following alignments, which denotes when in the frequency interval calculations are made.

arguments.name: DESC
arguments.description: specifies a descriptive label for the Delta-Normal analysis. Longer labels are truncated to 80 characters.

arguments.name: EVALDATE=
arguments.description: updates the value of the _date_ variable after market state generation. In particular, this affects subsequent method calls and result calculations.

arguments.name: INTERVAL=
arguments.description: specifies the frequency with which to compute VaR. Valid interval names are YEAR, SEMIYEAR, QTR, MONTH, SEMIMONTH, TENDAY, WEEK, WEEKDAY, and DAY.

arguments.name: OUTVARS
arguments.description: specifies one or more of the following dependent variables to analyze:

statements.name: DISTORTION
statements.description: Requests additional risk measures based on distortion functions. These functions are either defined in the SASHELP library or are user-defined.

arguments.name: name
arguments.description: specifies a name for the distortion risk measure. This name appears as a column in the SimStat data set.

arguments.name: FUNC
arguments.description: specifies the distortion function from which the distortion risk measure is computed. SAS Risk Dimensions provides the following distortion functions.

arguments.name: PARM
arguments.description: specifies the parameter value or values associated with the chosen distortion function given by the FUNC argument. For any distortion function with a parameter, the PARM argument is required.

arguments.name: DESC
arguments.description: specifies a description for the distortion measure induced by the distortion function. The specified description appears as column headings in the SimStat data set.

arguments.name: DISTRIBUTION
arguments.description: specifies the distribution from which the distortion risk measure is calculated.

arguments.name: LOSS_MEASURE
arguments.description: applies only to the output variables where COMPTYPE=PL. Specifies whether the measure should be calculated from the profit or loss distribution. This is particularly important for measures that focus on the tail of the distribution.. If you do not specify this flag for an output variable with COMPTYPE=PL, values are reported as losses. Losses are positive values while profits are the negative of the losses.

arguments.name: LOSS
arguments.description: applies only to the output variables where COMPTYPE=PL. Specifies whether the measure should be calculated from the profit or loss distribution. This is particularly important for measures that focus on the tail of the distribution.. If you do not specify this flag for an output variable with COMPTYPE=PL, values are reported as losses. Losses are positive values while profits are the negative of the losses.

arguments.name: PROFIT_MEASURE
arguments.description: applies only to the output variables where COMPTYPE=PL. Specifies whether the measure should be calculated from the profit or loss distribution. This is particularly important for measures that focus on the tail of the distribution.. If you do not specify this flag for an output variable with COMPTYPE=PL, values are reported as losses. Losses are positive values while profits are the negative of the losses.

arguments.name: PROFIT
arguments.description: applies only to the output variables where COMPTYPE=PL. Specifies whether the measure should be calculated from the profit or loss distribution. This is particularly important for measures that focus on the tail of the distribution.. If you do not specify this flag for an output variable with COMPTYPE=PL, values are reported as losses. Losses are positive values while profits are the negative of the losses.

arguments.name: MINREPS
arguments.description: specifies the minimum number of nonmissing replications for the risk measure to be valid. For example, if you want a 99% VaR, then specify at least 100 replications. If your minimum number of replications is not consistent with the distortion measure and simulated distribution that you specify, then the distortion measure columns added to the SimStat data set contain missing values.

statements.name: DRIVER
statements.description: Creates driver objects, which define collections of risk factors that can be perturbed in a scenario analysis. The risk factors to be perturbed must be listed explicitly in the scenario definition.
statements.help:
DRIVER   driver-name  INSTVARS= (list) | LOANVARS= (list) | RISKFACTORS= (list) | 
	 DRIVERS= (list) <argument(s)>;

arguments.name: driver-name
arguments.description: specifies the name of the driver object.

arguments.name: INSTVARS=
arguments.description: specifies a list of instrument variables, risk factors, or drivers. To accommodate industry-specific terminology, you can specify INSTVARS as LOANVARS. At least one instrument variable, risk factor, or driver must be specified to create a valid driver. The values of specified instrument variables should be risk factor names.

arguments.name: LABEL=
arguments.description: provides a description of the driver.

arguments.name: LONGLABEL=
arguments.description: specifies a long description for the driver. Maximum length is 512 characters.

statements.name: DRIVERCHECK
statements.description: Chooses instrument variables for drivers within the context of the specified portfolio.

arguments.name: PORTFOLIO=
arguments.description: specifies the portfolio in which instrument variables for drivers are chosen.

arguments.name: OUTVALIDINSTVAR=
arguments.description: creates a data set that lists all of the instrument variables in the current environment that are candidates for use in drivers.

arguments.name: PARTIAL
arguments.description:
considers an instrument variable to be a candidate for use in drivers when one of the following occurs:
• when any value of that variable is a risk factor name in the environment
• when all the values of that instrument variable are missing

arguments.name: COMPLETE
arguments.description: considers an instrument variable to be a candidate for a driver only when all values of that variable are risk factor names in the environment.

statements.name: ENVIRONMENT
statements.description: Creates, saves, or updates an environment.
statements.help: ENVIRONMENT  NEW= *env-name*  <*argument(s)*>; ENVIRONMENT  OPEN= *env-name*  <*argument(s)*>; ENVIRONMENT  REPLACE= *env-name*  <*argument(s)*>; ENVIRONMENT  SAVE <*argument*>; ENVIRONMENT  SAVEAS= *env-name*  <*argument(s)*>;

arguments.name: NEW=
arguments.description: creates a new environment.

arguments.name: OPEN=
arguments.description: opens the specified environment as the current environment and clears the temporary working environment.

arguments.name: REPLACE=
arguments.description: replaces the specified environment as the current environment.

arguments.name: SAVE
arguments.description: saves changes made in the temporary working environment as permanent updates to the current environment.

arguments.name: SAVEAS=
arguments.description: saves changes made in the temporary working environment as permanent updates to the specified environment.

arguments.name: AUTOSAVE
arguments.description: automatically saves changes that are made in the temporary working environment as permanent updates to the current environment when the RISK procedure terminates. This argument is valid if NEW, OPEN, or REPLACE is specified.

arguments.name: NOAUTOSAVE
arguments.description: automatically saves changes that are made in the temporary working environment as permanent updates to the current environment when the RISK procedure terminates. This argument is valid if NEW, OPEN, or REPLACE is specified.

arguments.name: DESC
arguments.description: specifies a descriptive label for the environment. Longer labels are truncated to 80 characters. This argument is valid if either NEW, OPEN, or REPLACE is specified.

arguments.name: INHERIT=
arguments.description: enables inheritance for the environment from the contents of one or more specified environments. This argument is valid if either NEW, OPEN, or REPLACE is specified and replaces any existing inheritance structure that is specified for the environment. To add one or more environments to an existing inheritance structure, use the INCLUDE argument.

arguments.name: INCLUDE=
arguments.description: enables inheritance for the environment from the contents of one or more specified environments in addition to any from which the environment already inherits. To specify an inheritance structure that replaces any existing inheritance structure that is specified for the environment, use the INHERIT argument.

arguments.name: LONGLABEL=
arguments.description: specifies a long description for the environment. Maximum length is 512 characters.

arguments.name: NOUPDATEMETADATA
arguments.description: turns off updates to metadata repositories. When you specify metadata SAS system options, the SAVE or SAVEAS argument of the ENVIRONMENT statement updates metadata repositories with the environment’s name, location, and description. For example, if the SAS METAREPOSITORY system option is set, updates are made to the metadata repository unless you specify NOUPDATEMETADATA.

statements.name: FILTER
statements.description: Creates a logical expression or query that selects a subset of a portfolio to use in an analysis.

arguments.name: name
arguments.description: specifies the name of the filter.

arguments.name: WHERE
arguments.description: specifies conditions of the filter expressed in the syntax of the SAS programming language. Variables used in the conditional expression must be instrument variables that are included in all of the instrument types, either when the types are defined or through inheritance of the BASETYPE instrument type.

arguments.name: DESC
arguments.description: specifies a descriptive label for the filter. Longer labels are truncated to 80 characters.

arguments.name: LONGLABEL=
arguments.description: specifies a long description for the filter. Maximum length is 512 characters.

statements.name: IMPORT
statements.description: Imports objects from the specified environment to the current temporary working environment.

arguments.name: FROM
arguments.description: specifies the environment from which to import objects.

arguments.name: ANALYSIS=
arguments.description: imports one or more analysis specifications.

arguments.name: CROSSCLASS=
arguments.description: imports one or more cross-classifications.

arguments.name: FILTER=
arguments.description: imports one or more portfolio filters.

arguments.name: INSTDATA=
arguments.description: imports one or more instrument data sources.

arguments.name: INSTRUMENT=
arguments.description: imports one or more instrument types. This argument performs the same function as the ACCOUNT, ASSET, and POLICY arguments.

arguments.name: MARKETDATA=
arguments.description: imports one or more market data sources.

arguments.name: METHOD=
arguments.description: imports one or more methods.

arguments.name: PARAMETER=
arguments.description: imports one or more parameter matrices.

arguments.name: PROJECT=
arguments.description: imports one or more analysis projects.

arguments.name: RFTSET=
arguments.description: imports one or more risk factor transformation sets.

arguments.name: SCENARIO_CF=
arguments.description: imports one or more scenario cash flow data objects.

arguments.name: SOURCE=
arguments.description: imports one or more portfolio input lists.

arguments.name: TIMEGRID=
arguments.description: imports one or more time grids.

arguments.name: VARIABLE=
arguments.description: imports one or more instrument, counterparty, or mitigation variables.

statements.name: INSTDATA
statements.description: Creates an instrument data source, which the READ statement uses to create a risk object used in a portfolio. To accommodate industry-specific terminology, you can also call the INSTDATA statement the LOANDATA statement.
statements.help: INSTDATA   *data-source-name*  FILE= *SAS-data-set*  FORMAT= *data-format*  <*argument(s)*> ; LOANDATA   *data-source-name*  FILE= *SAS-data-set*  FORMAT= *data-format*  <*argument(s)*> ;

arguments.name: data-source-name
arguments.description: specifies the name of the instrument data source.

arguments.name: FILE=
arguments.description: specifies the input data set (or data view) that contains the instrument data.

arguments.name: FORMAT=
arguments.description: specifies the type of the input data set.

arguments.name: DESC
arguments.description: specifies a descriptive label for the instrument data source. Longer labels are truncated to 80 characters.

arguments.name: LONGLABEL=
arguments.description: specifies a long description for the instrument data source. Maximum length is 512 characters.

arguments.name: TYPE=
arguments.description: specifies that all instruments in the input file have the same instrument type (namely that specified by the instrument-type-name). If the instrument type varies across instruments in the file, then do not specify this argument. Maximum length is 32 characters.

arguments.name: VARIABLES=
arguments.description: maps variable names in the input data set to instrument variable names.

statements.name: INSTRUMENT
statements.description: Creates an instrument type, which associates instrument variables with methods. To accommodate industry-specific terminology, you can also call the INSTRUMENT statement the ACCOUNT, ASSET, LOAN, or POLICY statement.

arguments.name: object-name
arguments.description: specifies the name of the instrument type.

arguments.name: BASETYPE
arguments.description: specifies the parent instrument type from which the instrument type inherits variables and pricing methods.

arguments.name: DEFAULT
arguments.description: specifies the default values of the instrument variables.

arguments.name: DESC
arguments.description: specifies a descriptive label for the instrument type. Longer labels are truncated to 80 characters.

arguments.name: LONGLABEL=
arguments.description: specifies a long description for the instrument type. Maximum length is 512 characters.

arguments.name: MCREPS=
arguments.description: specifies the number of times that instrument types are called when you perform a Monte Carlo pricing. Output variables are averaged across the specified number. The default value of number is 2. Use this argument when MCTYPE=AVERAGE.

arguments.name: MCTYPE=
arguments.description: specifies a Monte Carlo instrument type. This instrument type is supported by SAS High-Performance Risk. The associated pricing method is called in a loop MCREPS times across horizons, where you specify value through the value of MCREPS or the value of MCSIMULATIONS in the PROC HPRISK statement.

arguments.name: METHODS=
arguments.description: specifies the method programs to execute for instruments of this type, where method-name is the name of the method program. Pricing methods are executed to calculate the value of the instrument type in a specific market state.

arguments.name: VARIABLES=
arguments.description: specifies the variables that are associated with the instrument type.

arguments.name: VALRECORD=
arguments.description: specifies whether instruments of this type are quadratic.

statements.name: MARKETDATA
statements.description: Creates a market data source. The different types of market data sources include current market values, historical market data, risk factor covariance matrices, sensitivities, and others. To accommodate industry-specific terminology, you can also specify the ECONDATA statement or the PARAMETERDATA statement.
statements.help: MARKETDATA   *data-source-name*  FILE= *SAS-data-set*  TYPE= *type*  <*argument(s)*> ; ECONDATA   *data-source-name*  FILE= *SAS-data-set*  TYPE= *type*  <*argument(s)*> ; PARAMETERDATA   *data-source-name*  FILE= *SAS-data-set*  TYPE= *type*  <*argument(s)*> ;

arguments.name: data-source-name
arguments.description: specifies the name of the market data source that is created.

arguments.name: FILE=
arguments.description: specifies the input data set that contains the market data.

arguments.name: TYPE=
arguments.description:
specifies one of the following types of market data sources:
• CHANGES 
• CHOLESKY 
• CORRELATION 
• COVARIANCE 
• CURRENT 
• PARAMETER | PARAMETERS 
• RAREEVENTS 
• SCENARIOANALYSIS 
• SCENARIO_CF 
• SCENARIOS 
• SENSITIVITIES
• TIMESERIES 
• TRANSFORM 
• VOLATILITY

arguments.name: ALPOS
arguments.description: specifies whether to apply each position’s asset-liability position flag to data in the sensitivities market data source. The flag is a multiplier of 1 or of –1. The default value is NOALPOS. Use this argument only when you specify TYPE=SENSITIVITIES.

arguments.name: NOALPOS
arguments.description: specifies whether to apply each position’s asset-liability position flag to data in the sensitivities market data source. The flag is a multiplier of 1 or of –1. The default value is NOALPOS. Use this argument only when you specify TYPE=SENSITIVITIES.

arguments.name: CURRENCY=
arguments.description: specifies the three-letter currency code of the values in the sensitivities market data source. The default value is the numeraire currency of the project. Use this argument only when you specify TYPE=SENSITIVITIES. This argument is ignored when used with ALPOS, FX, HOLDING, or SHORTPOS.

arguments.name: FX
arguments.description: specifies whether values in the sensitivities market data source should be multiplied by the appropriate foreign exchange rate. The default value is NOFX. Use this argument only when you specify TYPE=SENSITIVITIES.

arguments.name: NOFX
arguments.description: specifies whether values in the sensitivities market data source should be multiplied by the appropriate foreign exchange rate. The default value is NOFX. Use this argument only when you specify TYPE=SENSITIVITIES.

arguments.name: HOLDING
arguments.description: specifies whether the value in the sensitivities market data source should be multiplied by the holding amount. The default value is NOHOLDING. Use this argument only when you specify TYPE=SENSITIVITIES.

arguments.name: NOHOLDING
arguments.description: specifies whether the value in the sensitivities market data source should be multiplied by the holding amount. The default value is NOHOLDING. Use this argument only when you specify TYPE=SENSITIVITIES.

arguments.name: INTERVAL=
arguments.description: specifies the data frequency. This argument is applicable when TYPE= AGGR_CONFIG, CHANGES, CHOLESKY, CORRELATION, COVARIANCE, RAREEVENTS, SCENARIOS, TIMESERIES, or VOLATILITY.

arguments.name: KEY=
arguments.description: specifies which column in the market data source to use as a key. The default value is InstID. The key must be both a column in the data source and an instrument variable.

arguments.name: PSD=
arguments.description:
specifies whether you have validated that a covariance or correlation matrix is positive semidefinite. Setting this argument often reduces run time by skipping validations, but you assume greater responsibility for the quality of your data.
• In a Delta-Normal analysis, the process ordinarily validates that the covariance matrix is positive semi-definite before calculating VaR. By specifying PSD=VERIFIED, you specify to skip this validation. 
• In a simulation analysis, a Cholesky decomposition of the matrix is performed. If during the Cholesky decomposition a negative pivot point is calculated, the process ordinarily fixes the matrix according to the specification of PSDMETHOD= in the SETOPTIONS statement. By specifying PSD=VERIFIED, you specify that the negative pivot is numeric noise. In that case, the pivot is set equal to 0.

arguments.name: ROWNAME=
arguments.description: specifies another name for the variable _name_, if it is in the input data set.

arguments.name: SHORTPOS
arguments.description: specifies whether the value in the sensitivities market data source should be multiplied by the short position flag. The default value is NOSHORTPOS. Use this argument only when you specify TYPE=SENSITIVITIES.

arguments.name: NOSHORTPOS
arguments.description: specifies whether the value in the sensitivities market data source should be multiplied by the short position flag. The default value is NOSHORTPOS. Use this argument only when you specify TYPE=SENSITIVITIES.

arguments.name: TOLERANCE=
arguments.description: sets the tolerance for Cholesky and spectral decompositions. The value should be between 1e-16 and 1e-4. If you do not specify this argument, then a tolerance of 1e-8 is used.

statements.name: MITIGATION
statements.description: Creates a mitigation type that is associated with mitigation variables and methods. A mitigation method is required for a mitigation object.

arguments.name: name
arguments.description: specifies the name of the mitigation type.

arguments.name: BASETYPE
arguments.description: specifies the parent mitigation type from which the mitigation type inherits variables. If you specify this argument, the METHOD argument is not required.

arguments.name: DESC
arguments.description: specifies a descriptive label for the mitigation type. Longer labels are truncated to 80 characters.

arguments.name: LONGLABEL=
arguments.description: specifies a long description for the mitigation type. Maximum length is 512 characters.

arguments.name: METHOD=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the mitigation method. If you specify this argument, the BASETYPE argument is not required.

arguments.name: VARIABLES=
arguments.description: specifies the variables that are associated with the mitigation type.

statements.name: MITIGATIONDATA
statements.description: Creates a mitigation data source, which the READ statement uses to create a risk object used in a portfolio.

arguments.name: data-source-name
arguments.description: specifies the name of the mitigation data source.

arguments.name: FILE=
arguments.description: specifies the input data set (or data view) that contains the mitigation data.

arguments.name: DESC
arguments.description: specifies a descriptive label for the mitigation data source. Longer labels are truncated to 80 characters.

arguments.name: LONGLABEL=
arguments.description: specifies a long description for the mitigation data source. Maximum length is 512 characters.

arguments.name: TARGET=
arguments.description: specifies whether the mitigation data source uses position-level mitigation or netting set-level mitigation. The default value is POSITION.

arguments.name: TYPE=
arguments.description: specifies that all mitigants in the input file have the same mitigation type (namely that specified by mitigation-type-name). If the mitigation type varies across mitigants in the file, then do not specify this argument. Maximum length is 32 characters.

arguments.name: VARIABLES=
arguments.description: maps variable names in the input data set to mitigation variable names.

statements.name: PARAMETER
statements.description: Creates a static parameter matrix, which holds numerical constants. Static parameter matrices can be accessed but not modified.

arguments.name: pmx
arguments.description: specifies the name of the parameter matrix.

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: specifies a parameter or transform market data source from which to read parameter values.

arguments.name: DESC
arguments.description: specifies a descriptive label for the parameter matrix. Longer labels are truncated to 80 characters.

arguments.name: DIMENSION
arguments.description: specifies the dimensions of a dynamic parameter matrix. If you specify the DIMENSION argument, then do not specify the ROW or COLUMN arguments.

arguments.name: LINTRANS
arguments.description: specifies whether the parameter matrix is for a linear transformation of risk factors. If the LINTRANS argument is invoked, then both the COLUMN and ROW arguments must be specified, and each value that these arguments specify must represent a risk factor.

arguments.name: NOLINTRANS
arguments.description: specifies whether the parameter matrix is for a linear transformation of risk factors. If the LINTRANS argument is invoked, then both the COLUMN and ROW arguments must be specified, and each value that these arguments specify must represent a risk factor.

arguments.name: LONGLABEL=
arguments.description: specifies a long description for the parameter matrix. Maximum length is 512 characters.

arguments.name: MAXNAMELEN=
arguments.description: specifies the maximum length of the name of a row or a column in a parameter matrix. The length must be an integer between 1 and 1024. Names must be unique to the first 32 characters.

arguments.name: PMXCOLUMN=
arguments.description: specifies which rows to filter when columns of data in a parameter matrix are accessed.

statements.name: PROJECT
statements.description: Creates a collection of portfolio, analysis, and output objects. These objects must be previously defined in other RISK procedure statements. Many of the arguments in the PROJECT statement are also available in the RUNPROJECT statement.

arguments.name: project-name
arguments.description: specifies the name of the project.

arguments.name: PORTFOLIO=
arguments.description: specifies the portfolio to analyze.

arguments.name: ALTYPE
arguments.description: triggers the following:

arguments.name: ANALYSIS=
arguments.description: specifies an analysis to use.

arguments.name: CFBUCKETLIST
arguments.description: lists multiple cash flow bucketing specifications to use simultaneously. Cash flow buckets are used to aggregate the cash flows at cross-classifications.

arguments.name: CFDIST=
arguments.description: A cash flow that occurs on a bucket date always goes into that bucket. The CFDIST argument specifies a distribution method to handle cash flows that do not fall exactly on a bucket date. Cash flows accumulate into either the previous or following bucket.

arguments.name: CFMAX
arguments.description: specifies the maximum cash flow size for all the instruments in the project. Use this argument for managing memory. If not specified, the argument is set to 10,000.

arguments.name: COMPUTEDMETHODS=
arguments.description: specifies one or more computed methods or computed_rollup methods to use.

arguments.name: CPTYINPUTMETHODS=
arguments.description: specifies one or more input methods to run when TASK=DISTRIBUTE in the HPRISK procedure. The specified list of input methods runs once for each counterparty as it distributes the CPTYDATA, enabling you to set or update the values of counterparty input variables in the portfolio.

arguments.name: CROSSCLASS=
arguments.description: specifies the cross-classification to use. If you do not specify this argument, then results are computed only for the entire portfolio.

arguments.name: DATA
arguments.description: specifies one or more market data sources to use. You can use market data to help set base case values for the risk factors. In particular, you can include current, volatility, and time series to compute lags.

arguments.name: DESC
arguments.description: specifies a descriptive label for the project. Longer labels are truncated to 80 characters.

arguments.name: INPUTMETHODS=
arguments.description: specifies one or more input methods to run when TASK=DISTRIBUTE in the HPRisk procedure. The specified list of input methods runs once for each position as it distributes the INSTDATA, enabling you to set or update the values of instrument variables in the portfolio.

arguments.name: LONGLABEL=
arguments.description: specifies a long description for the project. Maximum length is 512 characters.

arguments.name: NUMERAIRE
arguments.description: specifies the three-letter currency code of the currency in which to report results. If this argument is not specified, then USD (U.S. dollars) is the reporting currency.

arguments.name: OPTIONS=
arguments.description: specifies values for any of the analysis and output arguments that are available in the SETOPTIONS statement.

arguments.name: POSTVARMETHODS=
arguments.description: specifies one or more PostVaR methods to use.

arguments.name: PREQUERYMETHODS=
arguments.description: specifies the list of PreQuery methods to run during a query.

arguments.name: PROJECTMETHODS=
arguments.description: specifies one or more project methods to use.

arguments.name: RFTSET=
arguments.description: specifies one or more risk factor transformation sets to apply to the input market data.

arguments.name: ROLLUPMETHODS=
arguments.description: specifies one or more rollup methods to include in the risk project.

arguments.name: RUNDATE=
arguments.description: specifies a date constant (for example, ’1jan1999’d) to use as the base date of the project.

statements.name: READARRAYS

To view a data set with this format, execute the WRITEARRAYS statement and examine the resulting output data set.

statements.name: READREFS
statements.description: Defines reference maps for risk factors.

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: specifies the input data set that contains the reference map attributes. This data set must have the same format as the output data set that is specified in the WRITEREFS. To view a data set with this format, execute the WRITEREFS statement and examine the resulting output data set.

statements.name: READTYPES
statements.description: Creates instrument type declarations.

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: specifies the input data set that contains the instrument types. This data set must have the same format as the output data set that is specified in the WRITETYPES statement. To view a data set with this format, execute the WRITETYPES statement and examine the resulting output data set.

arguments.name: ANALYSISGROUP=
arguments.description: specifies an analysis group to reference when writing scenarios to an output data set.

arguments.name: LONGLABEL=
arguments.description: specifies a long description for the instrument type. Maximum length is 512 characters.

arguments.name: MCTYPE=
arguments.description: specifies a Monte Carlo instrument type. This instrument type is supported by SAS High-Performance Risk. The associated pricing method is called in a loop the number of times specified by the value of MCREPS in the INSTRUMENT statement or the value of MCSIMULATIONS in the PROC HPRISK statement.

statements.name: READVARS
statements.description: Creates variable declarations.

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: specifies the input data set that contains the variable attributes. This data set must have the same format as the output data set that is specified in the WRITEVARS statement. To view a data set with this format, execute the WRITEVARS statement and examine the resulting output data set.

arguments.name: DIMENSIONS=
arguments.description: tells SAS Risk Dimensions to look in those extra columns in the data set specified by DATA argument for values of dimension variables. If a value associated with a certain dimension is missing, then that dimension is not part of the variable declaration. The following code tells SAS Risk Dimensions to create a variable declaration as defined in the MYLIB.MYVARS SAS data set:

statements.name: READ_MODELGROUPS
statements.description: Replaces the models for mapped instruments and products within the specified model group.

arguments.name: GROUPS=
arguments.description: specifies the data set that contains a one-to-one mapping of an instrument (product) type to a model group.

arguments.name: MODELS=
arguments.description: specifies the data set that contains a 1–N list of models per model group and their corresponding model method.

statements.name: RFTSET
statements.description: Creates a risk factor transformation set. This set lists transformation methods, linear transformation market data sources, and previously created risk factor transformation sets to use to derive the values of risk factor variables from the market data.

arguments.name: name

arguments.name: LINTRANS=
arguments.description: specifies linear transformations parameter matrices that you defined in a previous call to the PARAMETER statement.

arguments.name: METHODS=
arguments.description: specifies risk factor transformation methods that you previously defined using the COMPILE procedure.

arguments.name: RFTSET=
arguments.description: specifies transformation sets that you defined in a previous call to the RFTSET statement.

arguments.name: DESC
arguments.description: specifies a descriptive label for the risk factor transformation set. Longer labels are truncated to 80 characters.

arguments.name: LONGLABEL=
arguments.description: specifies a long description for the risk factor transformation set. Maximum length is 512 characters.

statements.name: SCENARIOCF
statements.description: Creates a scenario cash flow data object to use with the READ_SCENARIO_CF CALL routine. The data object and the CALL routine work together to provide cash flow data by analysis, instrument ID, and simulation replication (or scenario) to a pricing method.

arguments.name: scenariocfobj
arguments.description: specifies the name of the scenario cash flow market data object.

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: specifies the scenario cash flow market data source that contains the cash flow data.

arguments.name: VALUE
arguments.description: specifies that the associated method’s _Value_ variable is set from the market data set. Using this argument prevents the COMPILE procedure from producing an error that the _Value_ variable is not explicitly set within the method.

arguments.name: LEGLIST
arguments.description: specifies the list of cash flow legs or types that are set in the market data set. This argument directs the RISK procedure to allocate memory for the cash flow legs.

arguments.name: DESC
arguments.description: specifies a description for the scenario cash flow data object. Labels longer than 80 characters are truncated.

arguments.name: LONGLABEL=
arguments.description: specifies a long description for the scenario cash flow data object. Maximum length is 512 characters.

statements.name: SENSITIVITY
statements.description: Creates a sensitivity analysis specification based on the base case market state. This specification computes the vector of partial derivatives and, if requested, the Hessian matrix of second-order partial derivatives of the portfolio value with respect to specified risk factor variables. Sensitivity computations use either numerical differentiation of the pricing function or an explicit analytical formula that depends on the type of instrument. The formula is incorporated into the pricing method program that is associated with the instrument type.

arguments.name: name
arguments.description: specifies the name of the sensitivity analysis specification.

arguments.name: DESC
arguments.description: specifies a descriptive label for the sensitivity analysis specification. Longer labels are truncated to 80 characters.

arguments.name: EVALDATE=
arguments.description: updates the value of the _date_ variable after market state generation. In particular, this affects subsequent method calls and result calculations.

arguments.name: HESSIAN
arguments.description: computes the matrix of second-order partial derivatives.

arguments.name: INSTID=
arguments.description: specifies the prefix to use for names that are assigned to the instID variable in the output data set.

arguments.name: INSTTYPE=
arguments.description: specifies the name to assign to the InstType variable in the output data set.

arguments.name: LONGLABEL=
arguments.description: specifies a long description for the sensitivity analysis specification. Maximum length is 512 characters.

arguments.name: OUTVARS
arguments.description: specifies one or more of the following dependent variables to analyze:

arguments.name: THETA
arguments.description: computes sensitivity with respect to the valuation date.

arguments.name: VARIABLES
arguments.description: specifies the risk factor variables to use in the analysis. If you do not specify this argument, sensitivities are computed with respect to all risk factors.

statements.name: SETOPTIONS
statements.description: Enables you to specify environment-level arguments to control the behavior of analysis, output, and general system functionality in the RISK procedure.

arguments.name: ALPHA=
arguments.description: specifies the quantile that defines VaR. It is a value between 0 and 1. If you do not specify this argument, then ALPHA=0.05.

arguments.name: BANDWIDTH=
arguments.description: specifies the bandwidth parameter for the kernel density estimation algorithm that is used to compute probability density curves from the simulated values. It is a value between 0 and 1. If you do not specify this argument, then BANDWIDTH=0.5.

arguments.name: COMPRESS=
arguments.description: specifies the principal component analysis (PCA) compression rate, which is a value between 0 and 1. A value of 1 specifies no compression, a value of 0.85 specifies 15% compression, and so on. A compression rate greater than or equal to 0.75 is recommended. If you do not specify this argument, no compression is performed.

arguments.name: EPSILON=
arguments.description: specifies the value of the scale parameter, which controls the size of the risk factor perturbations that are used to compute finite difference approximations to partial derivatives of the instrument values. This value must be greater than or equal to 1.0e – 12 and less than or equal to 1. If you do not specify the EPSILON argument, then the scale parameter is set to 1.0e – 4. This argument is used with the HLWBND argument.

arguments.name: EVTCUTOFF=
arguments.description: specifies the percentage of sample points in the tail to use in tail index estimation for generation of extreme value statistics. It is represented by an integer value between 1 and 50. This value should be greater than or equal to the quantile that is specified by the ALPHA argument. For example, if ALPHA= .10, which represents the 90th percentile, then the value of EVTCUTOFF= should be greater than or equal to 10. If the value is smaller than the quantile that is specified by the ALPHA argument, then extreme value statistics are not generated.

arguments.name: HLWBND=
arguments.description: specifies a lower bound for the size of the risk factor perturbations that are used to compute finite difference approximations to partial derivatives of the instrument values. This value must be greater than or equal to 1.0e – 15 and less than or equal to 1. If you do not specify the HLWBND argument, then the lower bound is set to 1.0e – 6.

arguments.name: KERNEL=
arguments.description: specifies the type of kernel to use in the kernel density estimation algorithm that is used to compute probability density curves from the simulation values. If you do not specify this argument, then a normal kernel is used.

arguments.name: NDENSITY=
arguments.description: specifies the number of points on the probability density curves to compute from the simulation values. It is a power of two between 8 and 1,024. Large values of NDENSITY= require more calculation time, but they produce smoother density estimate curves. If you do not specify this argument, then 32 points are computed.

arguments.name: PCA
arguments.description: specifies whether to perform PCA, in which a principal component decomposition is used to compute the principal eigenvalues and eigenvectors according to the specified compression rate. If you do not specify this argument, then PCA is not performed.

arguments.name: NOPCA
arguments.description: specifies whether to perform PCA, in which a principal component decomposition is used to compute the principal eigenvalues and eigenvectors according to the specified compression rate. If you do not specify this argument, then PCA is not performed.

arguments.name: PCTLDEF=
arguments.description: specifies the definition used to calculate quantiles. See "Calculating Percentiles" in the UNIVARIATE procedure for more information about quantile definitions. The default value is 1; this differs from the default of 5 with the UNIVARIATE procedure.

arguments.name: PSDMETHOD=
arguments.description: specifies the method used to adjust non-positive-semidefinite matrices for use in covariance simulations. SPECTRAL specifies the spectral decomposition method that is discussed in Rebonato and Jackel. DOWNWEIGHT specifies a more computationally tractable method. Using the Power Method, the smallest eigenvalue of the matrix is estimated and used to scale the off-diagonal elements. Although this method is faster than the spectral method, its use is not encouraged because of how it reduces covariances. It is maintained primarily for legacy purposes.

arguments.name: VARDEF=
arguments.description: specifies how the variance is calculated. If VARDF=N, then the denominator is the number of observations (n). If VARDEF=DF, then the denominator is n – 1. This argument also affects how skewness and kurtosis are calculated.

arguments.name: VAROPTDROP=
arguments.description: specifies the portion, a value between 0 and 1, of tail points to drop in VaR optimization using the algorithm described by Larsen, Mausser, and Uryasev (2001). If you do not specify this argument, then half of the tail points are dropped.

arguments.name: METASUFFIX=
arguments.description: enables you to choose whether to append the run date to the name of metadata objects that are created when the project runs. These metadata objects, such as data sets and risk environment tables, relate to the creation of information maps to display project results. The default value is TIMESTAMP.

arguments.name: OUTFOLDER=
arguments.description: specifies a folder in the metadata repository in which to place data sets, OLAP risk environment tables, and information maps that are created during a project run. You must specify this argument to build risk environment tables and information maps.

arguments.name: OUTMETALIB=
arguments.description: specifies a library on the metadata repository that is used to register data sets that are relevant to the OLAP risk environment tables that are created during a project run. You must specify this argument to build risk environment tables and information maps.

statements.name: SIMULATION
statements.description: Creates a simulation analysis specification. This specification first computes the distribution of the value of a portfolio under simulated market states at specified future times. It then produces results such as density curve estimates, risk factor statistics, and sensitivity measures.

arguments.name: name
arguments.description: specifies the name of the simulation analysis specification.

arguments.name: ALIGN=
arguments.description: specifies one of the following alignments, which denotes when in the frequency interval calculations are made:

arguments.name: COVDATA
arguments.description: specifies a covariance or correlation data set name. If you specify this argument, then the covariances or correlations that are in the data source replace those that are generated from the fitted models. This replacement is particularly useful when data is unavailable. Otherwise, the error covariance matrix would be block diagonal.

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: specifies one or more market data sources to use in the simulation.

arguments.name: DESC
arguments.description: specifies a descriptive label for the batch simulation analysis specification. Longer labels are truncated to 80 characters.

arguments.name: ENDDATE=
arguments.description: specifies the last date or datetime of time series data to use in covariance and historical simulations. If you do not specify this argument, then the end date is determined by the data in the input data set.

arguments.name: GENERATOR
arguments.description: specifies one of the following types of pseudorandom or quasi-random number generators to use:

arguments.name: HORIZON=
arguments.description: specifies the horizon to simulate and calculate results for. Specify integers between and including 1 and 23767.

arguments.name: INTERVAL=
arguments.description: specifies the simulation frequency. Valid interval names are YEAR, SEMIYEAR, QTR, MONTH, SEMIMONTH, TENDAY, WEEK, WEEKDAY, and DAY. This argument determines what input data and simulation models drive the simulation.

arguments.name: LAMBDA=
arguments.description: specifies the weight, between 0.0 and 0.9999, to use for computation of covariance matrices for residuals in Monte Carlo simulation. If you do not specify this argument, then weights are not used.

arguments.name: LONGLABEL=
arguments.description: specifies a long description for the simulation analysis specification. Maximum length is 512 characters.

arguments.name: METHOD=
arguments.description: specifies one of the following simulation methods for generation of simulated market states:

arguments.name: NDRAW
arguments.description: specifies the number of simulation replications, where n less-than 100,000 comma 000 n < 100,000 ,000 .

arguments.name: OUTVARS
arguments.description: specifies one or more of the following dependent variables to analyze:

arguments.name: OVERLAP
arguments.description: specifies whether time intervals overlap in historical simulations when the horizon specified is larger than 1. For example, if you specify that time intervals overlap, then the second interval in a calculation is used as the first interval in subsequent calculation. If you specify that time intervals do not overlap, then no interval is used more than once. The OVERLAP argument enables you to generate more simulation replications than with the NONOVERLAP argument applied to the same historical data set.

arguments.name: NONOVERLAP
arguments.description: specifies whether time intervals overlap in historical simulations when the horizon specified is larger than 1. For example, if you specify that time intervals overlap, then the second interval in a calculation is used as the first interval in subsequent calculation. If you specify that time intervals do not overlap, then no interval is used more than once. The OVERLAP argument enables you to generate more simulation replications than with the NONOVERLAP argument applied to the same historical data set.

arguments.name: PIVOT
arguments.description: specifies whether to pivot during Cholesky decomposition of a covariance or correlation matrix. If you do not specify this argument, then pivoting is not done.

arguments.name: NOPIVOT
arguments.description: specifies whether to pivot during Cholesky decomposition of a covariance or correlation matrix. If you do not specify this argument, then pivoting is not done.

arguments.name: SEED=
arguments.description: specifies a positive integer to use as the seed of a pseudorandom number generator, if one is specified. If you do not specify this argument, then the seed used is 54,321. Ten-digit integers less than 2 Superscript 31 minus 1 2 31 - 1 are valid seeds.

arguments.name: SHRINKAGE
arguments.description: specifies whether to use a shrinkage approach to calculate an estimate of the covariance matrix. This argument is valid for a covariance simulation if the input is a time series market data source. If you do not specify this argument and you perform a covariance simulation with a time series market data source, the sample covariance matrix is used instead of the shrinkage estimator.

arguments.name: NOSHRINKAGE
arguments.description: specifies whether to use a shrinkage approach to calculate an estimate of the covariance matrix. This argument is valid for a covariance simulation if the input is a time series market data source. If you do not specify this argument and you perform a covariance simulation with a time series market data source, the sample covariance matrix is used instead of the shrinkage estimator.

arguments.name: STARTDATE=
arguments.description: specifies the first date or datetime of time series data to use in covariance and historical simulations. If you do not specify this argument, then the start date is determined by the data in the input data set.

statements.name: SOURCES
statements.description: Creates a portfolio input list of portfolio data sources. These can be counterparty data sources, instrument data sources, and mitigation data sources. Portfolio input lists are used to create portfolios; instruments are read from all the associated data sources into the portfolio.

arguments.name: name
arguments.description: specifies the name of the portfolio input list.

arguments.name: data-source
arguments.description: specifies one or more portfolio data sources.

arguments.name: ( data-source-list )
arguments.description: specifies one or more portfolio data sources.

arguments.name: DESC
arguments.description: specifies a descriptive label for the portfolio input list. Longer labels are truncated to 80 characters.

arguments.name: LONGLABEL=
arguments.description: specifies a long description for the portfolio input list. Maximum length is 512 characters.

statements.name: TIMEGRID
statements.description: Creates a time grid, which you can use to specify lags to hold lag values of risk factors or to construct risk factor curves.

arguments.name: name
arguments.description: specifies the name of the time grid.

arguments.name: number_n time-unit
arguments.description:
specifies an amount of time in one of the following:
• a standard interval: DAY, WEEK, MONTH, or YEAR 
• a customized interval that you created

arguments.name: DESC
arguments.description: specifies a descriptive label for the time grid. Longer labels are truncated to 80 characters.

arguments.name: LONGLABEL=
arguments.description: specifies a long description for the time grid. Maximum length is 512 characters.

statements.name: TRANSMAT
statements.description: Creates a transition matrix, which is used to model a Markov chain process where the possible credit quality of the obligor is mapped to multiple states (potential rating grades).

arguments.name: transition-matrix-name
arguments.description: specifies the name of the transition matrix.

arguments.name: CDF=
arguments.description: specifies the cumulative distribution function (CDF) to use for conversion from probabilities to thresholds. You can specify either a distribution that is recognized by the SAS CDF function or you can supply a user-defined function. For more information about the SAS CDF function, see the SAS Language Reference: Dictionary. If you do not specify this argument, then the CDF is assumed to be the identity function.

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: specifies the input data set and, if multiple matrices of different time periods are included in the data set.

arguments.name: DESC
arguments.description: specifies a descriptive label for the transition matrix. Longer labels are truncated to 80 characters.

arguments.name: DYNAMIC
arguments.description: generates the matrix dynamically from the simulated states. In this case, the elements of the transition matrix are determined by the simulated economic conditions and are usually simulated or derived from simulated risk factors.

arguments.name: INTERVAL=
arguments.description: specifies the interval of the input matrix. Valid interval names are YEAR, SEMIYEAR, QTR, MONTH, SEMIMONTH, TENDAY, WEEK, WEEKDAY, and DAY. If you do not specify an interval, then YEAR is used. This argument is not valid if the DYNAMIC argument is specified.

arguments.name: INVCDF=
arguments.description: specifies the inverse of the CDF that is specified by the CDF argument. This user-defined function is needed for conversion from thresholds to probabilities.

arguments.name: LONGLABEL=
arguments.description: specifies a long description for the transition matrix. Maximum length is 512 characters.

arguments.name: ROWS
arguments.description: specifies the names of the states in the Markov chain, such as the symbols for all the possible rating grades. The n rows and n columns of the transition matrix are identified by these state names.

arguments.name: TRANSITION_FROM=
arguments.description: specifies the horizon from which to calculate the transition matrix. PREV or PREVIOUS is the default and derives the matrix as a power from the previous horizon. BASE or BASECASE derives the matrix as a power from the base case.

arguments.name: TYPE=
arguments.description: specifies one of the following types of the transition matrix:

statements.name: WRITEARRAYS
statements.description: Writes information about the arrays that are declared in the current environment to a SAS data set. The data set can be subsequently read with the READARRAYS statement.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the output data set.

statements.name: WRITEREFS
statements.description: Writes information about the reference maps that are declared in the current environment to a SAS data set. The data set can be subsequently read with the READREFS statement.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the output data set.

statements.name: WRITETYPES
statements.description: Writes information about the instrument types that are declared in the current environment to a SAS data set. The data set can be subsequently read with the READTYPES statement.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the output data set.

arguments.name: ANALYSISGROUP=
arguments.description: specifies the analysis group from which to select scenario analyses. The name is an analysis group created with the ANALYSISGROUP statement or one read by the READSCENARIOS statement.

arguments.name: LONGLABEL=
arguments.description: specifies a long description for the instrument type. Maximum length is 512 characters.

arguments.name: MCTYPE=
arguments.description: specifies a Monte Carlo instrument type. This instrument type is supported by SAS High-Performance Risk.

statements.name: WRITEVARS
statements.description: Writes information about the variables that are declared in the current environment to a SAS data set. The data set can be subsequently read with the READVARS statement.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the output data set.
